post.description:
Removes all Nexus Dashboard Multi-Cluster data from this cluster. This operation will be prevented if any active features are dependent on features from other members of the Multi-Cluster.
- When used on a primary cluster, all other Nexus Dashboard clusters must first be disconnected.
- When used on a secondary cluster, this blocks further communication with all other clusters in the Multi-Cluster group.
  - This will not affect the Multi-Cluster listing on the other clusters.

clusterHealthCheckType.description:
Cluster health check type.
  1. probes: Probes detects a non-responsive resource. For example, network connectivity.
  2. usageThreshold: Tracks resource utilization to a configured threhold. 
  3. performanceMetrics: Monitor the performance of configured resource to identify the 
        performance bottleneck in terms of latencies, rates etc.

metricUnit.description:
Specifies metrics unit type. 1. timeDuration: A duration string is a possible signed sequence of decimal numbers, 
    each with optional fraction and a unit suffix, such as "300ms"
2. quantity: Quantity is a fixed-point representation of a number. This is as 
    defined by Kubernetes https://Kubernetes.io/docs/reference/Kubernetes-api/common-definitions/quantity/
3. percentage: Number expressed as a fraction of 100. 4. custom: Custom configuration. Metrics value will provide exact condition details.

clusterHealthConfigK8s.description: Health check configuration to monitor Kubernetes cluster.

name.description:
Health check name etcdHealth:     Health check to monitor ETCS quorum. corednsHealth:  Coredns health check performs following checks:
                1. connectivity to forwarding servers.
                2. Make sure forwarding server is valid DNS server 
                    and can resolve non local cluster queries.
                3, health of coredns servers running within cluster.
coreCluster:    Core Kubernetes cluster health as defined by K8 health
                endpoint.
statefulSetsHealth: Health of Kubernetes StatefulSets:
                1. Make sure number of replicas matches to configured value.
                2. All pod configurations (images etc.) are in sync to configured values.
deploymentsHealth: Health of Kubernetes Deployments:
                1. Make sure number of replicas matches to configured value.
                2. All pod configurations (images etc.) are in sync to configured values.
daemonSetsHealth: Health of Kubernetes DaemonSets:
                1. Make sure number of replicas matches to configured value.
                2. AAll pod configurations (images etc.) are in sync to configured values.            
podsHealth:     Health check validates if all pods are in healthy state.

Health check name. cpuUsage:             Monitors node level CPU usage. memoryUsage:          Monitors node level memory usage. diskUsage:            Monitors disk usage across different 
                       partitions on disks.
diskIo:               diskIo is measured in terms of sync latency using fio. networkRtt:           Network RTT is measured via ping across nodes within 
                      cluster.
networkConnectivity:  Network connectivity is performed via pinging 
                      data network IP from each node to its peers node.     
nodeReadiness:        Node readiness is checked via Kubelet to verify if node is 
                      ready to schedule pods.
nasConnectivity:      Network Attached Storage (NAS) connectivity check verifies 
                      if each node within cluster can reach and mount NAS based
                      volumes.
networkLinksStatus:   Health check to monitor network links status. systemServices:       Health check to make sure core operating system services 
                      are running healthy. These services include storage daemons, 
                      kubelet, runtime services etc.
remoteServers:        Remote services includes checks to validate externally 
                      configured remote services. These services include DNS, NTP, 
                      syslog, splunk, network proxy.
ntp:                  Remote NTP servers health. ntpSyncStatus:        NTP Sync status to ensure clock is synchronized. bgp:                  BGP Peering status if configured for L3 service routing. dns:                  Remote DNS servers health. syslog:               Remote Syslog servers health. splunk:               Remote Splunk servers health. httpProxy:            Remote HTTP Proxy servers health. operStatus            Current Operational State of the node.

Reboot mode  1. reset: Power cycle the node. 2. clean-reset: This will wipe out all services data but will  
    preserve bootstrap configuration.
3. factory-reset: This will factory reset the node; all data including bootstrapping configuration will be erased.
    bootstrapping configuration will be erased.

Bootstrap state of this node.
  1. unknown: state is not currently known.
  2. discovering: Node is currently being discovered.
  3. unregistered: Node id has been discovered but node is still in unregistered state.
  4. incompatible: Software version is incompatible.
  5. registered: Node has been registered.

operationalState.description: operational state of this node. 1. inactive: Node is not part of cluster. 2. active: Node is registered and active. 3. deleted: Node has been deleted from the cluster. 4. rebooting: Node is currently going through a reboot. 5. suspended: Valid only for primary node type where that node has been suspended for a subsequent RMA. 6. replaceInProgress: Node is currently being replaced. 7. failoverInProgress: Node is currently being failed over. 8. failoverFailed: Node failover has failed. 9. replaceFailed: Node replacement has failed.

ntp.description: Remote NTP service allows ND cluster to synchronize with an NTP server to ensure time consistency. NTP servers and keys are separate list in order to allow sharing  of NTP keys across servers.

keyList.description: List of NTP security key configuration.

serverList.description: List of NTP remote server configuration.

ntpKeyConfig.description: NTP key configuration. NTP key is shared between a client running on ND Cluster and on  remote NTP server in order to secure the exchange of time information.

id.description: Unique Key ID within ND cluster.

key.description: Shared NTP key between client and remote server. Following rules are applied: - Key length should be atleast 8 characters. - Key length should not be more than 40 characters. - Key can contain printable ASCII characters excluding "#" or hex string. - Key longer than 20 characters is assumed to be a hex string.

trusted.description: Specifies whether this key is a trusted key.  When NTP authentication is enabled,  ND will only synchronize with time servers that send data with trusted key. default: false

keyID.description: key; id must be defined under the keys list.

preferred.description: Marks the server as preferred. All other things being equal, this host will be chosen for time synchronization among a set of correctly operating hosts. default: false

onboardUrl.description:
IP address or FQDN used to onboard the cluster.
For Nexus Dashboard clusters -
  Using an FQDN will enable cross-launch to this cluster from other Nexus Dashboard clusters using an FQDN. Otherwise, node management IPs will be used.
  A valid FQDN satisfies the format "<node-name>.<domain". Equivalent FQDNs using the same domain must exist for each other node in the secondary cluster.
  On the primary cluster, there must be one search domain that creates a valid FQDN for each primary cluster node.

systemFirmwareInstallType.description:
Installation type: factoryInstall: This is disruptive mode of firmware install. Complete
                cluster state including services data and bootstrap 
                configuration will be erased. This requires re-bootstrapping 
                of cluster. 
upgrade:        Software upgrade. Services will be disabled and upgraded 
                to target release version. Services state will be restored. 
                Please note, this is not in-service upgrade as services will 
                go down hence maintenance window is required to perform the 
                upgrade.

operation.description:
Last firmware operation. Typical workflow for firmware:
  download -> verify -> install  

download:   Download firmware. verify:     Verify firmware, installer validates integrity and authenticity 
            of firmware. Verification can fail due to one of following 
            reasons:
              1. Corrupted image, installer failed to verify digest and signature.
              2. Duplicate image, version of image is already present. 
validate:   Validate if cluster is ready to proceed with upgrade.  install:    Install firmware. Cluster must be in ready state to trigger 
            firmware install/upgrade. 
delete:     Delete firmware. This can happen in two cases.
            1. User deleted a downloaded firmware. Firmware can be only 
               if it has not yet been installed.
            2. Upgrade has finished and installer has deleted previous 
               version of release firmware.

name.description:
Upgrade stage name.  shutdownServices   Shutdown services to upgrade software packages. shutdownCore       Shutdown core infra services, this is required 
                   if core service needs to be upgraded. 
                   All the nodes will be rebooted to perform upgrade.
bootInstall        Install boot components required for the upgrade. rebootNodes        Reboot all cluster nodes to apply the upgrade. activateCore       Activate core infra services from target release. activateServices:  Activate services from target release.  running:           Release is installed/upgraded successfully. 
                   No further actions are allowed on this release.. 
superseded:       Release is superseded by a newer version. 
                   This release cannot be used to upgrade or install.
firmwareInstall: Release is installing firmware
In case of failures, statusDetails contains additional information about the  failure and steps to recover from failed upgrade.

  failedToProcess:      SMU processing/validation failed.

securityGroupId.description: Security Group ID with 0 to 15 reserved and cannot be used for user created security groups. Security Group ID '0' is assigned to name 'Any' which is used to classify any endpoint. Security Group ID '15' is assigned to name 'SG_DEFAULT~GPO_UNAWARE' which is used for classifying endpoints belonging to an unaware GPO Nexus fabric. This field is not editable during update.

vlanId.description:
VLAN value of PortGroup (PG) or Distributed Port Group (DVSPG). For PG, the VLAN options that the user can choose in vCenter and the corresponding value in this field are given below:
When user choses "None", this field will have a value of "0"
When user configures a value, this field will return the same. Foe example, "61"
For DVSPG, the VLAN type that the user can choose in vCenter and the the corresponding value in this field are given below:
When user selects the type as "None", this field will have a value of "0"
When user selects the type as "Access" and configures a value, this field will return the same. For example, "61"
When user selects the type as "Trunk" and configures a range, this field will return the same. For example, "100-200"
